Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Optimized Receiver Design Integration for Diversity and Cooperative Transmissions Beyond Belief Propagation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This work develops a novel receiver methodology to integrate signal detection and forward
error correction in multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) communications and various diversity
transmissions. Moving beyond traditional approaches relying on belief-propagation, this
investigation into the rather classic open problem of integrated signal detection and decoding
involves novel joint optimization formulations that incorporate binary field parity constraints
imposed by the low-density parity check within maximum likelihood detection frameworks for
unified optimization. This novel framework is general and encompasses a number of practical
transmission models, including distributed antennas, opportunistic cooperative networking,
and signal retransmission as well as their integrations. This project has broad impacts on
engineering, education, and society. Its success can lead to new research directions, new
tools, and results to help advance other science and engineering fields.

Focusing on multicarrier MIMO signal reception, the investigators will develop and optimize
integrated receivers for important wireless network diversities including distributed
transmissions, cooperative MIMO, and hybrid-ARQ retransmission systems. The new design
methodology emphasizes integration of multiple constraints from incompatible fields. By
reformulating and relaxing joint detection and decoding problems into convex optimization, the
investigators will design high performance receivers that are efficient and are robust to various
forms of uncertainties in channel state information. Such a novel approach to receiver design
integration represents a fundamental and practical design paradigm that can fully utilize
various a priori signaling and code constraints for joint detection and decoding against channel
distortions and other non-idealities to achieve high performance, efficiency, and reliability. The
research findings can contribute practically to improvement of future wireless services and
broaden their applications in many practical fields where quality, efficiency, and distributivity
concerns are paramount.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project develops a novel receiver methodology for wireless communication devices.  It unifies signal detection and error correction in multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) wireless communications for various diversity channels and network scenarios. It presents novel joint formulations that can incorporate optimization problems that span two traditionally incompatible mathematical fields to achieve a unified receiver optimization. This novel joint optimization framework is generally applicable to a number of practical scenarios.

In this research project, the PI and coworkers achieved several major technical outcomes accomplishments. First, the research team developed a linear-programming receiver architecture for joint detection and decoding of multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) communication signals under the protection of forward error correction codes. This work proposed a novel integration of the objective functions and constraints that previously were approximated only via belief propagation algorithms with limited success. The PI's group also developed joint detection-decoding receivers for bandwidth efficient hybrid ARQ and cooperative networking systems.  The team further proposed new framework for design optimization of MIMO transceivers in practical wireless systems driven by finite alphabet inputs under various networking scenarios such as cooperative relay and co-channel access of cellular physical resources.  The PI and coworkers derived novel algorithms for spectrum allocation and power control in heterogeneous wireless networks that are non-disruptive to high-priority users.

A number of peer-reviewed articles reporting these and other findings have been published in 28 journal papers, 1 US patent application, 5 PhD dissertations, and 8 conference papers.

The research findings have significant practical impact on the improvement of future wireless services and their applications in many practical fields where quality, efficiency, and simplicity are paramount concerns. The PI mentored and trained 5 PhD students who have completed their dissertations with the support of this research grant. To help create a diverse hi-tech workforce, two of the five PhD graduates are female and are now placed in Google and Facebook, respectively.  We have also worked with our industrial partner (Fujitsu Lab) to deveop and test new networking algorithms. The project findings have been broadly disseminated through conference presentations, journal manuscripts, seminars, and group website http://www.ece.ucdavis.edu/~zding.
